Pineda, J.M. Palacios * Instituto de Catdlisis y Petroleoquimica, CS1C, Campus Universidad Autdnoma, Cantoblanco, 28049-Madrid, Spain Received 30 August 1995; accepted 30 October 1995 Abstract Using a kinetic equation derived from results obtained in a differential reactor, a grain model with variable properties was applied to calculate the global reaction rate for a particle. Further- more, the theoretical model was developed to explain the performance of alumina as a catalyst for the Claus reaction at low temperature in an integral fixed bed reactor. The results were in good agreement with the experimental ones. The theoretical model was used to study the influence of the most significative parameters involved and to predict the catalyst performance in conditions of practical interest. It was shown that high H2S conversions and efficiencies of the catalyst were to be expected using highly porous materials and small particle sizes. These are the most important parameters for practical utilization. Keywords: Alumina; Claus reaction; Hydrogen sulphide; SuLphur I. Introduction The Claus reaction at high temperature (ca. 240) using ]/-AI2O3 as a catalyst is used as a second step in the Claus industrial process for the elimination of sulphur compounds from natural gas and oil desulphurization products. H2S conversions close to those expected from thermodynamic consid- erations are achieved [1,2]. The elemental sulphur gas formed as a reaction product is cooled and trapped in the liquid state. * Corresponding author. Palacios /Applied Catalysis A: General 136 (1996) 81-96 Since it is an exothermic process, higher H2S conversions could be expected if the reaction temperature were lowered (ca. 100). However, for practical use the rate of reaction should be kept high enough and the solid sulphur, in this case formed and retained in the catalyst, should not deactivate it, at least, until high levels of retained sulphur are reached. Previous results [3] have shown that H2S conversions higher than 90% can be achieved using HzS concentrations in the range 1-5% with a relatively slow catalyst deactivation. These figures make the Claus process at low temperature a potential technological process of great interest, especially, if the operation conditions and catalyst properties could be optimized. 2. Experimental Microcrystalline y-alumina with a pore volume Vp = 0.33 cm3/g and specific BET nitrogen surface area S = 185 mZ/g was used as a catalyst for the Claus reaction in a stainless steel upflow fixed bed reactor 1 cm id. The reactants, HzS and SO2, were fed from cylinders with mass flow controllers and passed through a water evaporator where the saturated vapor pressure was reached. The temperature of the reaction chamber was thermostated at 100 and the reaction temperature measured by a thermocouple immersed in the catalytic bed. The observed variations of temperature were less than 5 with reference to the set value. Some of the elemental sulphur not retained in the catalytic bed was trapped in a refrigerator situated downstream. The inlet and outlet gases of the reactor were analyzed by GC using a thermal conductivity detector. The experiments have been undertaken at a reaction temperature T = 100, atmo- spheric pressure, total flow of inlet gases F = 250 cm3/min, inlet gas composi- tion CH~s = 4 VO1.-%, CSO2 = 2 VOI.-%, N2 = balance and bed mass of catalyst m = 0.69 g. 3. In fact, in an integral reactor, presumably, fresh surfaces are only exposed to the reactants at the first instant, then a sulphur film of increasing thickness progressively plugs the pores deactivating the catalyst. In a previous study [11], it was assumed that the sulphur blocked the active sites located on the alumina surface and, consequently, catalyst deactivation followed a square law of the coating. This deactivation function was included as a correction factor in the kinetic equation and introduced directly in the mass balance equation for the fixed bed reactor. This model predicted a steep gradient of sulphur concentration along the bed that has not been evidenced experimen- tally. The composition of the inlet reactant gases was selected for practical interest and the remaining operation conditions are those most frequently used in this study. For a catalyst of small particle size (dp= 0.05-0.10 ram) it was possible to achieve high outlet HzS conversions with high efficiency of the catalytic bed (high bead conversions Xb). However, if the particle size of the catalyst was larger (alp > 0.10 mm) high HzS conversions were only achieved during the first moments when the sulphur deposition was small. Afterwards, the catalyst had to be replaced or regenerated with a very poor efficiency. 4. Conclusions On the basis of the kinetic results using alumina as a catalyst for the Claus reaction at low temperature, the grain model with variable properties was applied to calculate the global reaction rate of a catalyst particle as a function of the mean particle conversion Xs. These data was used to determine the behavior in a fixed bed reactor. The theoretical results agreed reasonably well with the experimental results and, consequently, the model was further used to predict the performance in other conditions of practical interest. It was shown that the Claus reaction in the fixed bed reactor at the test conditions was mostly controlled by intraparticle diffusion and, consequently, pore size and particle diameter were the most important parameters to be considered for the optimiza- tion of the catalyst. High HzS conversions with high efficiencies of the catalyst were only expected with highly porous materials and small particle sizes. 96 Acknowledgements The authors are support. M. Pineda, J.M. Using a kinetic equation derived from results obtained in a differential reactor, a grain model with variable properties was applied to calculate the global reaction rate for a particle. Furthermore, the theoretical model was developed to explain the performance of alumina as a catalyst for the Claus reaction at low temperature in an integral fixed bed reactor. The results were in good agreement with the experimental ones. The theoretical model was used to study the influence of the most significative parameters involved and to predict the catalyst performance in conditions of practical interest. It was shown that high H2S conversions and efficiencies of the catalyst were to be expected using highly porous materials and small particle sizes. These are the most important parameters for practical utilization. Keywords Alumina Claus reaction Hydrogen sulphide Sulphur References [1] G.R. Schoofs Hydrocarbon Proc. 2 1985 71 [2] D.
